questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with severe headache, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, disorientation, and fruity breath odour after consuming homemade liquor 12 hours ago. Blood gas analysis shows pH 7.25, bicarbonate 12 mmol/L, and anion gap metabolic acidosis. What is the drug of choice for his condition?
questions.explanation:
• Adulteration in Country liquor.
  • Solvent in industrial processes.
  • Antifreeze.

Mechanism of Action
  • Methanol ⟶ Formaldehyde (oxidation by alcohol dehydrogenase).
  • Formaldehyde ⟶ Formic acid (oxidation by aldehyde dehydrogenase).
  • Formic Acid ⟶ Inhibition of Cytochrome c Oxidase ⟶ Cellular Hypoxia and Metabolic Acidosis.

Features of Toxicity
  • CNS: Headache, dizziness, confusion, ataxia, seizures
  • Ocular: Blurred ("snowfield" vision).
  • Gastrointestinal: Nausea, vomiting, fruity breath and abdominal pain
  • Metabolic: Severe metabolic acidosis, elevated anion gap

Treatment

Mnemonic: SHAFE

  • Sodium Bicarbonate to correct metabolic acidosis
  • Hemodialysis to remove methanol and its metabolites
  • Antidote: Fomepizole or Ethanol to inhibit ADH
  • Folinic acid or folic acid to enhance formate metabolism.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male came to the clinic complaining of constipation for several days. A few weeks ago, he experienced diarrhoea after returning from Thailand, which was resolved after taking loperamide and ornidazole. What medication is best suited for relieving this patient's symptoms
questions.explanation:
Agent

Representative

Mechanism of action

Bulk laxatives

Soluble (Psyllium)

Insoluble (wheat bran)

Retaining water in stools, increasing

Stool softeners or wetting agents

Decussate sodium

Decussate calcium

Promoting luminal water binding by detergent action and increasing stool bulk

Stimulant laxatives

Sodium picosulfate

Bisacodyl

Increasing intestinal peristalsis by acting in myenteric plexus; decreasing large intestine water absorption

Osmotic agents

Polyethyleneglycol (PEG)

Osmotic water binding

Mixed (not classified)

Dried plums

Stool bulking and osmotic action

questions.text: Match the following drugs based on their receptor activity: Drug Receptor 1. Butorphanol a. Partial Mu Agonist + Kappa Antagonists 2. Nalfurafine b. Pure Antagonists 3. Buprenorphine c. Pure Kappa Agonist 4. Naloxone: d. Partial Kappa Agonist + Mu Antagonist
questions.explanation:
Receptor

Pure Kappa Agonist

Partial Kappa Agonist + Mu Antagonist

Partial Mu Agonist + Kappa Antagonists

Pure Antagonists

(competitive block)

Drugs

Nalfurafine

Fedotozine

Eluxadoline

Asimadoline

Pentazocine (Partial

Mu agonist but acts as an antagonist)

Nalorphine

Butorphanol

Buprenorphine (binds mu receptor irreversibly)

Dezocine

Naloxone

Naltrexone (longest acting)

Nalmefene (Liver safe)

Naloxegol

Uses

1. Uremic pruritus in CKD (Nalfurafine)

2. Diarrhoea in IBS

1. Migraine (Intranasal Butorphanol)

1. Opioid deaddiction (Buprenorphine)

2. Analgesia (Dezocine)

1. Antidote for opioid poisoning (IV Naloxone)

2. Prevents relapse (Naltrexone)

3. Alcohol dependence (Nalmefene)

4. Morphine dependence, obesity (Naltrexone)

5. Opioid-induced constipation (Naloxol, methylnaltrexone)

S/E

Dysphoria or psychosis

Dysphoria or psychosis

Buprenorphine effects cannot be overcome by naloxone.

1. Naloxone: Hypertension, pulmonary oedema, arrhythmia

2. Naltrexone: Hepatotoxic

C/I

 

1. Opioid deaddiction (precipitate withdrawal)

2. Myocardial ischemia

Labor pain (neonatal respiratory depression)

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle aches, insomnia, and intense cravings for opioids. He admits to using heroin for the past five years, often injecting multiple times a day. He has attempted to quit several times but has always relapsed due to severe withdrawal symptoms. He expresses a strong desire to stop using heroin and asks for medical help to manage his addiction. Which of the following is the most effective medication for the treatment?
questions.explanation:
Opioid Deaddiction Drugs

Medication

Mechanism of Action

Methadone (DOC)

Full opioid agonist; binds to opioid receptors, providing similar effects to other opioids, preventing withdrawal symptoms and reducing cravings.

Methadone maintenance treatment has been used to treat opioid dependence.The opioid dependent patient takes a daily dose of methadone as a liquid or pill. This reduces their withdrawal symptoms and cravings for opioids.

 

Buprenorphine

Partial opioid agonist; binds to opioid receptors with a lower maximum effect than full agonists, reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms.

Naltrexone

Opioid antagonist; blocks the effects of opioids at their receptor sites, preventing euphoria and other opioid effects.

Lofexidine and Clonidine

Alpha-2 adrenergic agonist; reduces the physical symptoms of opioid withdrawal by inhibiting the release of norepinephrine.

Anti-histamines

questions.text: Which action will not be seen by mu (μ) receptor stimulation?

Mu receptors

Kappa receptors

Delta receptors

High affinity for morphine & its congeners.

High affinity for ketocyclazocine & dynorphin A.

High affinity for Leu/metenkephalins.

Analgesia: Supraspinal (μ1) + spinal (μ2)

Analgesia: Spinal (κ1) + Supraspinal (κ2)

Analgesia: Spinal + affective of supraspinal)

Respiratory depression

Respiratory depression (minimal)

Respiratory depression

Sedation

Dysphoria

Affective behaviour

Euphoria

Miosis (minimal)

Reinforcing actions

Miosis

Sedation

Reduced GI motility

Muscular rigidity

Dependence

Proconvulsant

Reduced GI motility

Reduced GI motility

Dependence (morphine type)

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with a history of schizophrenia has been prescribed an antipsychotic medication for the past few months. She presents to the clinic with complaints of muscle stiffness, restlessness, and occasional tremors. During the examination, the physician noted her difficulty sitting still and observed her hands shaking intermittently. Which of the following symptoms is NOT a presentation associated with antipsychotic drugs?
questions.explanation:
Typical Antipsychotics

Atypical Antipsychotics
  • Haloperidol - highest risk
  • Butyrophenones - potent D2 blockers with a high risk.
  • Thioxanthenes -lower prolactin risk (least D2 blocking activity)
  • Risperidone and paliperidone - high risk (due to ￪ P-glycoprotein affinity)
  • Pimavanserin and clozapine - lowest risk.

 

Condition

Onset

Treatment

Acute muscle Dystonia (Option C)

Within 1-5 days of starting antipsychotic

Administering antiparkinsonian agents such as diphenhydramine or benztropine intramuscularly.

Parkinsonism

Within 1 month

Benzhexol and benztropine (NOT Levodopa)

Akathisia (Option B)

(Most common EPS)

5–60 days

Anti-anxiety medications

  1. DOC: Propranolol (C/I: Asthma)
  2. Diazepam

Rabbit Syndrome

Months or years
  1. Antiparkinsonian agents.
  2. Amantadine is preferred due to less adverse cognitive effects.

Tardive Dyskinesia (Option A)

Late-onset adverse effect (after months or years)

Occurs due to D2 receptor supersensitivity and can be permanent, even after discontinuing antipsychotic medication.

Stop AP drugs & start Clozapine.

If symptoms persist, add Dopamine depleters (VMAT2 inhibitors)

  1. Valbenazine
  2. Tetrabenazine: DOC for Huntington's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following atypical antidepressants has the maximum risk of seizures?
questions.explanation:
Bupropion (Option D)
  • Norepinephrine dopamine reuptake inhibitor
  • Used for smoking cessation and weight loss
  • High risk of seizures

Trazodone (Option B)
  • Serotonin antagonist (5HT2 blocker) and reuptake inhibitor
  • DOC-Depression + erectile dysfunction
  • No sexual dysfunction side effects
  • No nausea and vomiting side effects
  • Can cause priapism

Mirtazapine, Mianserin (Option C)
  • Noradrenaline and selective serotonin antagonist
  • Side effects: Somnolescence, increased appetite, and weight gain
  • Used in depression with insomnia

Buspirone, Gepirone (Option A)
  • 5HT1a receptor partial agonist
  • Used to treat generalised anxiety disorder

Tianeptine
  • Serotonin reuptake enhancer
  • It also acts on opioid receptors and stimulates them
  • Used to treat depression

questions.text: Which of the following is false about MAO inhibitors?

options.label: A
options.text: Use with sympathomimetics can cause hypertensive crisis

options.label: B
options.text: It is contraindicated with tyramine-rich food

options.label: C
options.text: Selegiline is a selective MAO-B inhibitor

questions.correct_answer: D. Routinely used to treat depression
questions.explanation:
Types of MAO Inhibitors

Examples

Non-selective MAOIs

Phenelzine, Tranylcypromine

Selective MAO-A inhibitors

Moclobemide

Selective MAO-B inhibitors

Selegiline, Rasagiline (Option C)

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with excessive worry, restlessness, difficulty concentrating, muscle tension, and disturbed sleep for several months. He also experiences occasional panic attacks with palpitations, sweating, and a sense of impending doom. With a family history of anxiety disorders, he is diagnosed with Generalised anxiety disorder (GAD). Which of the following medications is most appropriate for initial treatment?

A 35-year-old woman presents with persistent low mood, loss of interest, fatigue, difficulty concentrating, feelings of worthlessness, and occasional thoughts of self-harm for the past six months. She has a family history of depression. Diagnosed with major depressive disorder (MDD), she is started on paroxetine. Which class of drug does paroxetine fall under?

A patient recovering from alcohol dependence on disulfiram developed a fungal infection and was given an antifungal medication. Shortly after, the patient developed symptoms reminiscent of a disulfiram-like reaction. Which of the following antifungal drugs is most likely to have caused this reaction?

A 45-year-old man presents with complaints of recurrent episodes of sudden jerking movements involving his arms and legs. He has no other medical conditions and has been prescribed an antiepileptic drug. Which of the following medications acts by blocking sodium channels?

questions.text: A patient who presented with progressive muscle weakness and atrophy alongside dysarthria is diagnosed with Lou Gehrig’s disease. All of the following drugs can be used to manage this condition except?
questions.explanation:
Direct action on the nervous system

Symptomatic (relieve spasticity)
  • Riluzole.
  • Edaravone.
  • Baclofen.
  • Tizanidine.
  • Clonazepam (should be used cautiously as it can cause respiratory depression in advanced ALS).

questions.text: A patient who was diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease and started on syndopa a few months ago now complains of worsening rigidity and dyskinesia in between brief periods of improvement. Which of the following is the least preferred add-on drug for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Phase

Description

“On” Phase

Periods of good motor function after levodopa dose

“Off” Phase

Sudden return of parkinsonian symptoms as drug effect wanes

Wearing Off

Gradual decline in drug efficacy before next dose

Freezing

Temporary inability to initiate movement (usually in “off” state)

Drug

Class/Target

Mechanism

Use in On-Off

Remarks

Entacapone

COMT inhibitor

Inhibits peripheral levodopa breakdown

Prolongs “on” time

Preferred COMT inhibitor

Tolcapone

COMT inhibitor

Inhibits central + peripheral COMT

Similar effect but with hepatotoxicity

Least preferred

Apomorphine

Dopamine agonist (rescue)

Direct D1/D2 receptor stimulation

Used for sudden “off” episodes

Rapid-acting, subcutaneous

Istradefylline

Adenosine A2A antagonist

Enhances dopaminergic activity in indirect pathway

Reduces “off” periods

Favorable side-effect profile

Selegiline

MAO-B inhibitor

Inhibits dopamine metabolism

Reduces wearing-off effects

Neuroprotective role suggested

Amantadine

NMDA antagonist

Increases dopamine release, reduces glutamate

Used for levodopa-induced dyskinesia

Add-on in advanced stages

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding GABA receptors is incorrect? GABA-A receptors are dimeric metabotropic receptors and mediate inhibitory neurotransmission. GABA-B receptors are inhibitory G protein-coupled receptors and mediate slow inhibitory neurotransmission through the efflux of potassium. Activation of GABA-A receptors results in the efflux of chloride ions into the neuron. α and γ subunits of GABA-A receptors modulate drug efficacy. GABA-C receptors are structurally and functionally similar to GABA-A receptors
questions.explanation:
Types

MOA

Drugs

GABA A
  • Pentameric ionotropic ligand-gated Cl– channels
  • 5 Subunits: 2 α, 2 beta and 1 γ
  • α and γ subunits affect the efficacy of benzodiazepine binding and channel modulation
  • Fast inhibitory neurotransmission through hyperpolarisation of the neurons by Cl- ion influx

1. Benzodiazepines (diazepam etc.)

  • Acts as a positive allosteric modulator
  • Increase the frequency of opening of the GABA-A receptor.

2. Barbiturates

  • Binds at multiple sites
  • Increase mean open time with no effect on frequency.

3. Volatile anaesthetics

4. Brexanolone (neuroactive steroid)

5. Ethanol

GABA B
  • Metabotropic inhibitory G protein-coupled receptor
  • Heterodimers with 2 subunits
  • Gi type of GPCR
  • Inhibit adenylyl cyclase, activate K+ channels (K+ efflux), and reduce Ca2+ conductance
  • Slow inhibitory neurotransmission

1. Baclofen (muscle relaxant)

2. gamma-hydroxybutyric acid ( narcolepsy)

GABA C
  • Ionotropic receptor
  • Structurally and functionally similar to GABA A receptors.
  • Location: Retina

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a history of glaucoma was recently diagnosed with primary Parkinson's disease and started treatment with syndopa (levodopa-carbidopa) therapy. The patient inquires about potential adverse events associated with the treatment. Which of the following statements is false? Nausea is the most common adverse effect due to the activation of D2 receptors inside the GIT. Dyskinesias and impulsiveness are common adverse effects associated with long-term levodopa use. Levodopa is contraindicated in this patient with a history of narrow-angle glaucoma. Long-term use of levodopa is associated with fluctuations in motor symptoms. Levodopa increases treatment efficacy with carbidopa.
questions.explanation:
Adverse events associated with Levodopa

Side effects

1. Peripheral side effects:

  • Nausea/ vomiting: (Statement 1)
    • Most common
    • Due to D2 receptor activation in CTZ outside the blood-brain barrier.
    • Treat with domperidone (Blocks D2 receptor)
  • Postural hypotension (D1 receptor-induced vasodilation)
  • Mydriasis (Stimulates alpha-1 receptor in the iris)
  • Arrhythmia (Stimulates cardiac beta-1 receptor)
 

Note: Combining Levodopa with peripheral dopa decarboxylase inhibitors (Carbidopa/Bensarazide) prevents peripheral side effects. (Statement 5)

 

2. CNS side effects:

  • Dyskinesia: Treat with Amantadine, Levetiracetam (Statement 2)
  • Psychosis: Clozapine, Quetiapine
  • Hypersexuality/impulsiveness
 

3. Wearing off phenomenon

  • Reduced effect of levodopa with decreased neuron number

 

4. On-off phenomenon: (Statement 4)

  • Fluctuating course of improved mobility followed by akinesia

Contraindications
  1. Angle-closure glaucoma (block trabecular outflow) (Statement 3) 
  2. Melanoma
  3. Peptic Ulcer Disease
  4. Psychosis
  5. In combination with vitamin B6/pyridoxine (increase peripheral conversion and side effects)
  6. In combination with MAO inhibitors (hypertensive crisis)

questions.text: What is the recommended therapeutic range for phenytoin?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Therapeutic Range

Phenytoin

10 to 20 mcg/ml

Valproate

40 to 100 mcg/ml

Phenobarbitone

10 to 30 mcg/ml

Carbamazepine

5 to 10 mcg/ml

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with severe, sharp, electric shock-like pain on the right side of her face. The pain, triggered by talking, chewing, and touching her face, lasts a few seconds to minutes and has become increasingly frequent and debilitating. Which of the following medications is the drug of choice for treating her condition?
questions.explanation:
Drug

Mechanism of Action

Uses

Side Effects

Carbamazepine

Inhibits high-frequency neuronal discharges and modulates voltage-gated sodium channels.

Trigeminal neuralgia, GTCS, partial seizures, bipolar disorder.

Sedation, dizziness, ataxia, GI disturbances, bone marrow suppression, hypersensitivity reactions, water retention.

Gabapentin

Enhances GABA release modulates voltage-sensitive Ca2+ channels.

Partial seizures, post-herpetic neuralgia, migraine prophylaxis.

Sedation, tiredness, dizziness, tremor, unsteadiness.

Diazepam

Enhances GABAergic neurotransmission.

Status epilepticus, Febrile seizure.

Thrombophlebitis, hypotension, respiratory depression.

Topiramate

Multiple mechanisms, including sodium channel inactivation, GABA potentiation, glutamate receptor antagonism, and potassium channel modulation.

GTCS, myoclonic epilepsy, and absence of seizures.

Impairment of attention, sedation, ataxia, word-finding difficulties, poor memory, weight loss, paresthesias, renal stones.

questions.text: A 12-year-old with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is on valproate for seizure control. During a follow-up, the neurologist reviews valproate's uses and potential side effects. Which of the following is NOT true regarding valproate?

options.label: A
options.text: Used in the treatment of Dravet syndrome

options.label: B
options.text: Drug of choice in atypical absence seizures

options.label: C
options.text: Used in the treatment of mania

questions.explanation:
Clinical Use

Explanation

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome

Approved and effective

Dravet syndrome

Used, especially if other options like stiripentol are limited

Atypical absence seizures

Drug of choice

Bipolar disorder (mania)

Used as mood stabilizer

Adverse Effects

Notable Points

Hepatotoxicity (especially in <2 y/o)

Black box warning

Pancreatitis

Rare but serious

Teratogenicity

Neural tube defects

Hyperammonemia

May cause encephalopathy

NOT associated with Purple Glove

This is linked to IV phenytoin, not valproate
